metadata.case_name: Atyam Veerraju (Trustee of Sri Janardhana Swami Varu) v. Nuli Subba Rao and others

facts.text: Suit lands: R.S. No. 153/3 (2 acres 38 cents) and R.S. No. 167 (4 acres 36 cents), totaling 6 acres 74 cents in Cherukuvada village, West Godavari District, Andhra Pradesh.

In 1851, Ponnuri Anandu (then Archaka and de facto trustee) arranged with Nuli Peda Narasimhulu (great grandfather of first defendant) that latter would supply one-fourth seer of gingili oil every day to temple and enjoy income of lands; arrangement reduced to writing (Sanad dated November 10, 1851).
First defendant and predecessors in possession under this arrangement.
Arrangement terminated by notices dated December 6, 1948 and August 31, 1949 issued by plaintiff's advocate to first defendant.
Second defendant is lessee under first defendant.
Plaintiff not trustee (contention negatived by lower courts, not pressed).
No arrangement as alleged; first defendant entitled to lands subject to supplying oil.
In 1851, Peda Narasimhulu was owner in possession; arrangement made when he was owner.
Arrangement amounted to permanent transfer for consideration, reserving only oil supply.
Uninterrupted possession for over a century, title by adverse possession subject to oil burden.
Suit filed a century after Ponnuri Anandu's death/termination, barred by time.
First defendant died pending suit; third and fourth defendants (legal representatives) substituted.
Subordinate Judge, Eluru: Lands belong to deity; 1851 arrangement permanent lease; adverse possession title acquired. Suit dismissed.
High Court confirmed decree on adverse possession, no opinion on ownership/lease.
Public records (Inam Fair Register Ex. A-4): Deity inamdar since 1795; sold to deity in 1851 for Rs. 120; confirmed 1859.
Re-settlement Register 1932 (Ex. A-6), Inam B Register 1934: Deity inamdar, Devadayam for Deeparadhana.
Hindu Religious Endowments Board scheme 1931 (confirmed 1937): Lands property of deity in possession of Nuli Subba Rao.
Defendants' documents (Exs. B-1 to B-8): Mortgages/leases by successors since 1895, reciting lands in deity's name but family possession under 1851 Sanad for Nanda Deepam.
Notice June 16, 1929 by Board demanding contribution; reply Oct 25, 1929 by Subba Rao denying, claiming under Sanad.
Defendants withheld Sanad despite notice; court infers adverse presumption.
Continuous possession and oil supply by defendants' family for over century since 1851.
Lands dry in 1851, later converted to wet, no rent increase/eviction attempts.
Suit instituted November 1, 1954.

legal_issues.text: Is the deity the owner of the suit lands?
If so, what rights were acquired by Peda Narasimhulu under the arrangement of 1851?
Have Peda Narasimhulu and his successors-in-interest acquired title to the lands by adverse possession subject to the burden of supplying one-fourth seer of gingili oil every day to the deity?

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit lands belong to deity; 1851 arrangement not alienation but license to receive income towards oil price; even if lease, right to terminate and recover lands.

respondent_arguments.text: No arrangement as alleged; entitled to lands subject to oil supply; Peda Narasimhulu owner in 1851.
1851 arrangement permanent transfer/lease for consideration, binding on deity.
Title by adverse possession over century.

court_reasoning.text: Deity owner per public records (Inam registers, etc.); defendants' documents admit deity's name in accounts; Sanad withheld, adverse presumption; reject claims of prior ownership by Peda Narasimhulu or Anandu.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deity is the owner of the lands.

court_reasoning.text: Sanad construction: Onus on defendants; long possession/oil supply consistent with yearly lease, not permanent; manager could grant yearly leases; withheld Sanad presumes against permanent tenancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sanad granted lease from year to year.

court_reasoning.text: No adverse possession: Possession permissive under lease till 1949; 1929 notice not to trustees, not notorious/hostile to start prescription; s.116 Evidence Act; cannot prescribe permanent right during tenancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Possession not adverse; suit within time under Art.139 Limitation Act.

holdings.text: Deity is owner of suit lands.
1851 Sanad granted yearly lease, not permanent tenancy or absolute title.
No title by adverse possession; tenancy determined 1949; suit not barred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sivayogeswara Cotton Press, Devangere v. M. Panchaksharappa
precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of lease deed for permanency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bjoy Gopal Mukherji v. Pratul Chandra Ghose
Maharanee Shibissouree Debia v. Mothooranath Acharjoo
precedents_cited.relevance: No presumption of permanent lease by endowment manager without necessity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Naini Pillai Marakayar v. Ramanathan Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Manager cannot grant permanent lease without necessity; no prescription by tenant.
Presume validity of ancient permanent lease for necessity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vidya Varuthi Thirtha v. Baluswami Ayyar
precedents_cited.relevance: Manager's lease endures only for tenure if unauthorised.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bilas Kunwar v. Desraj Ranjit Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Tenant cannot deny landlord's title during tenancy (s.116 Evidence Act).

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohammad Mumtaz Ali Khan v. Mohan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: No prescription of permanent occupancy during tenancy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madhavrao Waman Satindalgekar v. Raghunath Venkatesh Deshpande
Patna Municipal Corporation v. Ram Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Approval of no prescription by tenant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bastacolla Colliery Co. Ltd. v. Bandhu Beldar
precedents_cited.relevance: Not deciding on notorious claim exception.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act (Madras Act 2 of 1927)
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme framed for temple declaring lands as deity's property.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Tenant cannot deny landlord's title during tenancy.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act, 1908 (Act IX of 1908)
statutes_cited.relevance: No adverse possession; suit governed by Art.139.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Amendment Act (Act 1 of 1929)
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced Art.134-B, not applicable to lawful leases.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments of lower courts set aside; decree for trustees for possession of suit lands; trial court to enquire mesne profits.
outcome.relief_granted: Possession of suit lands; mesne profits enquiry.

key_quotes.text: We are satisfied that the deity is the owner of the lands.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves ownership issue in favor of deity.

key_quotes.text: The most striking feature of this case and the thing which tilts the scales against the defendants is the non-production of this Sanad.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: No tenant of lands in India can obtain any right to a permanent tenancy by prescription in them against his landlord from whom he holds the lands.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle on no adverse possession by tenant.
